did.abstract: This Collection details Marian Thompson’s experiences and recollections during her enlistment in the Vietnam War. The Collection contains an excerpt from Colonel Marian Thompson’s memoirs. The partial manuscript provides evidence of American “black outs” during World War II, working conditions for women during the 1940’s and 1950’s, U.S. Army enlistment incentives, and collaborative therapy programs between Japan and Vietnam, among other topics.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Born June 4, 1923, Marian Thompson enlisted in the Women’s Medical Specialist Corps while still a Physical Education teacher in the Farmington, CT school system. Interested in physical therapy, Marian applied, and was accepted as a student at the Brooke Army Medical School for her clinical training. Initially planning to take advantage of the one year of free education for one year of pay back time offered by the U.S. Army, Marian went on to serve for twenty years. She was commissioned a 2nd Lieutenant on September 24, 1953, 1st Lieutenant in March of 1955, and Colonel in June of 1974. Prior to her retirement in June of 1974, Colonel Thompson’s assignments included Fort Sam Houston, Fort Jackson, Walter Reed Medical Center, Camp Lama in Japan, Valley Forge General Hospital, Fort Leonard Wood, Letterman Army Medical Center, 3rd Field Hospital in Vietnam, and Fitzsimmons Army Medical Center.
